subject: Re: [junit] Re: Platform dependent JUnit testcases

messageBody:
On Mon, 23 Feb 2004, humbugzilla wrote:

> I was thinking that someone else might take the single testclass
> (potentially one of many) intended only for Windows and try to run it
> standalone on another platform, but I guess this boils down to a
> question of documenting the testcases properly including valid runtime
> environments.

If it's on the class level, I've used marker interfaces in the past to
indicate what can be used where. For example, for some customer tests
executed via junit I wanted to mark some as failing for the moment:

public interface FailingTestCase {
}

public class SomeTests extends TestCase implements FailingTestCase {
...
}

I one suite() method that would run all of the tests, and another that
would exclude the ones implementing FailingTestCase:

public class KnownWorking extends TestSuite {
public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
for (int i = 0; i < All.ALL_TEST_CLASSES.length; i++) {
Class testCase = All.ALL_TEST_CLASSES[i];
if (!NotKnownWorking.class.isAssignableFrom(testCase))
suite.addTestSuite(All.ALL_TEST_CLASSES[i]);
}
return suite;
}
}

That didn't work so well because I wanted to do things on a test method
by test method basis, so I switched to naming some methods with a
special prefix:

public class SomeTests extends TestCase {
public void testFoo() {
...
}
public void FAILINGtestBar() {
...
}
}

And then you can write your own little suite() method to deal with selecting
out the failing methods as well as the standard methods.

Maybe it would be simpler to just put an if statement at the beginning of
some tests:

public void testFoo() {
if (!platformIs(WINDOWS))
return;
...
}
